Award.AwardTitle: Labor Market Insecurity and Perceived Employability

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1626886
Arne Kalleberg
Lindsey King
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

As employment becomes more precarious and uncertain, workers are consistently advised to keep themselves sought-after in the labor market. Hence, perceived employability, or workers' beliefs in their ability to find an acceptable job, emerges as a fundamental issue for contemporary labor market research. Employed workers experience less stress when they are confident they can find a new, comparable job if they lose their present one. Unemployed workers who feel they are employable are more motivated to keep searching for jobs. While perceived employability is influenced by individuals' attributes, societal contexts also affect it. This project examines how country differences in labor market institutions and public policies are related to employed and unemployed workers' perceptions of their employability. The investigators hypothesize that perceived employability is bolstered by policies that promote labor market flexibility or help workers gain marketable skills, net of economic conditions. Understanding how these institutions and policies affect individuals' perceptions helps to comprehend better how social contexts matter for people's psychological well-being and career outcomes. This knowledge is essential for designing effective social and economic policies intended to help individuals manage the risks associated with the increasing uncertainty characterizing labor markets; it is also crucial for informing individuals' decisions about educational and training alternatives that are likely to help them to secure meaningful and rewarding jobs. Thus, the researchers will share the results of the project with policy-makers as well as both employed and unemployed individuals, in addition to scholars studying labor markets, work, and inequality.

How do workers perceive their ability to find work, and how do labor market policies shape this evaluation? Existing research suggests that both economic and regulatory conditions shape workers' evaluations of their employment prospects. Workers in market-oriented economies tend to be more confident in their employability than those in rigid labor markets, where labor market transitions from job to job or unemployment to employment are more difficult. This pilot study examines the relationship between labor market policies that facilitate transitions into new jobs and workers' perceptions of their employability. The research has two main objectives. First, the investigators use international survey data from Europe, East Asia, North America, and Oceania to examine the links between policy and perceived employability among both employed and unemployed workers. They hypothesize that perceived employability will be greater when unemployment is low, labor markets are flexible, and when countries provide support that helps workers become re-employed. Second, the researchers use longitudinal panel data from the United Kingdom to assess how employability perceptions impact the likelihood of future employment among unemployed workers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past several decades, the issue of perceived employability (i.e., the belief in one’s ability to find an acceptable job) has attracted significant scholarly and public interest.  Most research on this topic has focused on employed persons, but neglecting the unemployed limits the relevance of existing research to the experience of unemployment. Our research analyzed the factors that influence the perceived employability of both employed and unemployed persons.  We based our analysis on data collected in 2005 from 19 countries through the International Social Survey Program (ISSP); we supplemented these individual-level data with information on the institutions and policies of these countries from published sources.  We merged these two types of information to create a single, multi-level data set.

 

In all countries included in the study, the unemployed have less education on average than the employed. The college education gap is most pronounced in countries with flexible labor markets, such as the United States, where mobility requires general human capital that is easily transferred to new employment. When workers with specialized skills fall into unemployment, suitable job opportunities may be scarce. The education gap is also sizeable in East Asian countries, where companies invest heavily in core workers, giving them the advantage of high education and high job security. In most countries, the unemployed are younger on average than the employed, and are more likely to be women. While living with an employed partner can mitigate the strain of unemployment, the majority of jobseekers in any country are not in this situation; rather, employed workers are more likely to have employed partners. Overall, unemployed workers who lack education or financial stability are in an especially precarious position, potentially exacerbated by labor markets that offer few good job opportunities or policies that protect full-time, permanent workers at the expense of everyone else.

 

In general, we found that perceived employability rises with educational level and training. At the country level, certain indicators of job quality, labor market conditions, and policies affect perceived employability. First, the unemployed feel less employable as the incidence of precarious, temporary work in the country rises. When the unemployed gauge their employment options, the quality of possible jobs may matter as much as the quantity. Second, perceived employability is negatively affected by unequal protections for permanent and temporary work. When workers in standard employment relationships receive ample protection while other workers do not, the unemployed see fewer opportunities. Third, the unemployed perceive lower employability when long-term unemployment rates are high, though the overall unemployment rate has no significant effect. When assessing their employment prospects, the unemployed seem less concerned with labor market churn than with labor market immobility.

 

In ongoing research, we are updating our analysis to include recently released data collected in 2015 through the ISSP. This will enable us to assess the impacts of the economic crisis in the late 2000s on perceived employability, thereby permitting us to generalize the results described above.
